awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Versatile Robot Hands for Warehouse Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is clear from the size of the market in warehousing and logistics. The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that the annual cost of moving inventory by hand in warehouses is 5 billion dollars. Industry is eager to adopt new robotic technology, and it has already made a significant impact in many aspects of this problem, speeding shipments and lowering costs. However, handling individual items has not yet proven viable when the range of objects is large. The grasping robot developed in this project will meet this need, and reduce the cost of logistics for manufacturers, distributors, and customers. Additionally, the creation of robot grasping systems that can automatically grasp a wide range of objects will open up the benefits of robotic technology to workers in other industries. This is critical to making robots accessible to small manufacturing shops, and will significantly improve the performance of telepresence systems used for military, rescue, and consumer applications such as home assistance for the elderly.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project is based on a decade of university research on the design and construction of robots for grasping using passive mechanisms. Through the carefully tuned structural compliance of the fingers, robot hands can be designed to compensate for variation in the size, shape and location of grasped objects to obtain reliable grasps. During the course of this project, a commercial product will be developed capable of picking and placing a wide range of items at extremely low error rates, something that has hitherto been considered a hard problem in sensing and planning. The new compliant grippers, combined with breakthroughs in low-cost tactile sensing and simplified grasp planning, will enable a level of performance that meets the needs of real-world customers. The new picking robot will be validated against a set of realistic items picked from bins in a simulated warehouse environment.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop an integrated robot gripper and computer vision system capable of picking up and handling everyday commercial products, such as groceries, clothing, health and beauty items, and consumer electronics. Although the rapid rise of e-commerce has created a boom in the construction of warehouses for online order fulfillment, it has also put stress on warehouse workers, who must individually pick and pack each order. Already, some automation has eased this process, such as the much-publicized Kiva warehouse system purchased by Amazon in 2012. However, the problem of picking individual items out of boxes and totes has not yet been solved, and high turnover in these positions has been an impediment to the growth in the industry.

RightHand Robotics was founded to commercialize research from the Harvard Biorobotics Laboratory, which has been working developing gentler, more natural robot hands for over ten years. The Biorobotics Laboratory’s principal focus has been on passively adaptive robot hands, that is, robot hands that can move in response to contact from external objects without the need for sensing or active control. Passive adaptation enables reflex-like responses, and can dramatically simplify the hardware and software needed to mimic complex human tasks. The STTR project supported by the NSF is directed primarily at improving the mechanical reliability and cost of passively adaptive hands, so that they are capable of operating in a warehouse environment. The secondary goal has been the development of software for integrating knowledge of the hands’ passively adaptive behaviors into motion planners, so that real-world robotic picking tasks can be performed.

To date, RightHand Robotics has made commercially available a robot hand, the ReFlex Hand, whose performance has been sufficient to engage in fundraising and commercial exploration with warehouse operators. Development of software for controlling these hands in ongoing, and preliminary results have shown that the integrated hardware and software system is capable of executing thousands of picks across a wide variety of everyday objects. Thanks to this effort, RightHand Robotics is positioned to commercialize a decade's worth of academic research, and to use the company's products to solve a crucial problem in an increasingly important sector of the American economy.
